name.description: The name of your app as it appears both within Exponent and on your home screen as a standalone app.

description.description: A short description of what your app is and why it is great.

slug.description: The friendly url name for publishing. eg: ``exp.host/@your-username/slug``.

privacy.description: Either ``public`` or ``unlisted``. If not provided, defaults to ``unlisted``. In the future ``private`` will be supported. ``unlisted`` hides the experience from search results.

sdkVersion.description: The Exponent sdkVersion to run the project on. This should line up with the version specified in your package.json.

version.description: Your app version, use whatever versioning scheme that you like.

orientation.description: Lock your app to a specific orientation with ``portrait`` or ``landscape``. Defaults to no lock.

primaryColor.description: On Android, this will determine the color of your app in the multitasker. Currently this is not used on iOS, but it may be used for other purposes in the future.

meta.regexHuman: 6 character long hex color string, eg: ``'#000000'``

iconUrl.description: A url that points to your app's icon image. We recommend that you use a 512x512 png file with transparency. This icon will appear on the home screen and within the Exponent app.
Url that points to the icon to use for push notifications. 48x48 png grayscale with transparency.

color.description: Tint color for the push notification image when it appears in the notification tray.

meta.regexHuman: 6 character long hex color string, eg: ``'#000000'``

androidMode.description: Show each push notification individually (``default``) or collapse into one (``collapse``).

androidCollapsedTitle.description: If ``androidMode`` is set to ``collapse``, this title is used for the collapsed notification message. eg: ``'#{unread_notifications} new interactions'``.

loading.description: Configuration for the loading screen that users see when opening your app, while fetching & caching bundle and assets.

iconUrl.description: Url that points to the icon to display while starting up the app. Image size and aspect ratio are up to you. Must be a .png.

exponentIconColor.description: If no icon is provided, we will show the Exponent logo. You can choose between ``white`` and ``blue``.

exponentIconGrayscale.description: Similar to ``exponentIconColor`` but instead indicate if it should be grayscale (``1``) or not (``0``).

backgroundImageUrl.description: Url that points to an image to fill the background of the loading screen. Image size and aspect ratio are up to you. Must be a .png.

backgroundColor.description: Color to fill the loading screen background

meta.regexHuman: 6 character long hex color string, eg: ``'#000000'``

hideExponentText.description: By default, Exponent shows some text at the bottom of the loading screen. Set this to ``true`` to disable.

appKey.description: By default, Exponent looks for the application registered with the AppRegistry as ``main``. If you would like to change this, you can specify the name in this property.

meta.regexHuman: 6 character long hex color string, eg: ``'#000000'``

androidHideExponentNotificationInShellAp.description: By default, Exponent adds a notification to your app with refresh button and debug info. Set this to ``true`` to disable.

scheme.description: Url scheme to link into your app. For example, if we set this to ``'rnplay'``, then rnplay:// urls would open your app when tapped.

entryPoint.description: The relative path to your main JavaScript file.

extra.description: Any extra fields you want to pass to your experience.

bundleIdentifier.description: The bundle identifier for your iOS standalone app. You make it up, but it needs to be unique on the App Store. See `this StackOverflow question <http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11347470/what-does-bundle-identifier-mean-in-the-ios-project>`_.

meta.regexHuman: iOS bundle identifier notation unique name for your app. For example, host.exp.exponent, where exp.host is our domain and Exponent is our app.

buildNumber.description: Build number for your iOS standalone app

usesNonExemptEncryption.description: Sets ``ITSAppUsesNonExemptEncryption`` in the standalone ipa's Info.plist to the given boolean value.

fabric.description: `Twitter Fabric <https://get.fabric.io/>`_ keys to hook up Crashlytics and other services.

googleSignIn.description: `Google Sign-In iOS SDK <https://developers.google.com/identity/sign-in/ios/start-integrating>`_ keys for your standalone app.

reservedClientId.description: The reserved client id url scheme. Can be found in `GoogeService-Info.plist`.

supportsTablet.description: Whether your standalone iOS app supports tablet screen sizes.

package.description: The package name for your Android standalone app. You make it up, but it needs to be unique on the Play Store. See `this StackOverflow question <http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6273892/android-package-name-convention>`_.

meta.regexHuman: Reverse DNS notation unique name for your app. For example, host.exp.exponent, where exp.host is our domain and Exponent is our app.

versionCode.description: Version number required by Google Play. Increment by one for each release. https://developer.android.com/studio/publish/versioning.html.

fabric.description: `Twitter Fabric <https://get.fabric.io/>`_ keys to hook up Crashlytics and other services.

googleMaps.description: `Google Maps Android SDK <https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/android-api/signup>`_ key for your standalone app.

apiKey.description: Your Google Maps Android SDK API key

googleSignIn.description: `Google Sign-In Android SDK <https://developers.google.com/identity/sign-in/android/start-integrating>`_ keys for your standalone app.

apiKey.description: The Android API key. Can be found in the credentials section of the developer console or in `google-services.json`.

certificateHash.description: The SHA-1 hash of the signing certificate used to build the apk without any separator `:`. Can be found in `google-services.json`. https://developers.google.com/android/guides/client-auth

facebookScheme.description: Used for Facebook native login. Starts with 'fb' and followed by a string of digits, like 'fb1234567890'. You can find your scheme at https://developers.facebook.com/docs/facebook-login/ios in the 'Configuring Your info.plist' section.
